result.markdown:
--- title: Vowel fronting in human and animate plural forms author: Nikita Beklemishev, Nina Dobrushina date: 'Last update: 2024-05-01' output: html_document: number_sections: true anchor_sections: true pandoc_args: --shift-heading-level-by=-1 --- In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire. ## playHPLroot ::: {.panel-tabset} ### Map ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
